yourdigitalcoach: Thank you for sharing this. I too have felt like the one on the left and now just starting the journey to lean into the one on the right at the age of 44. But it started with a divorce and a failed business as the age of 39 so still moving into the ‘right’ direction. So tough but so rewarding. Imagine if we had a tribe to connect with and hold each other’s hand skipping towards the ‘right’? Sometimes it feels lonely and often it means friendships and relationships change as you lean into yourself. As you connect your heart, your mind and your gut to reveal the true self. Many people will be shocked with the change and many others will connect with the new you. But the gift of these new connections is that it’s a connection based on the ‘right’ you and so the connection is so much sweeter. ❤️🔥👏👊🎉
alyseruriani: i want to echo what people are saying about this post being triggering and equating thinnness with mental health. i’m a long time lover of bando and jen! and i have no doubt she did not mean for the post to come off this way to people, but unfortunately our intentions don’t always come through. before and afters that feature the body–especially of weight loss–despite the intention being about mental health, will always come off to some as an indication that equates the two. and the phrase “i look different because i feel different, not the other way around” still can be a problem because it can perpetuate the narrative that when you feel better you will be thinner and that being fat means you’re unhappy/unfulifilled/etc. also, yeah it’s disheartening that the sizing was not inclusive. again, love jen and love bando, but this missed the mark.

All the best for everything, you're a strong cookie and ROCKIN' this bikini! 💪🍪👙👌💐 Well done girl x

missbearkat: I love this post so much! 💕💕💕 Although a bit concerned about some of the criticism it’s receiving. I 100% agree that mental health and “being thin” do NOT go hand in hand. BUT I also feel like that’s not the point Jen is trying to make in this post. My big takeaways are that she stopped self medicating, faced her sadness head on and focused intensely on her mental health. She feels a “connection” with her body and that’s absolutely different than “I got thinner so I’m happy now!” As someone who deals with anxiety, depression and OCD... exercise is crucial for me to function. It’s freaking crucial. In needing that, my body has also transformed. Who are we to judge a person’s journey. Girl is saying she feels amazing, stronger and that her light is shining brighter. I wanna call things out when necessary FOR SURE but I also wanna celebrate all of us in our victories, no matter if the victory looks different than my own.
